meanings.definition: To produce suckers or shoots from the base or roots of a plant.
meanings.sent1: The tomato plant was suckering, sending out new shoots for more tomatoes to grow.
meanings.sent2: The gardener noticed the rose bush suckering, creating new branches from the base.
meanings.sent3: The apple tree seemed to be suckering happily, spreading its roots and shoots.
meanings.sent4: The vineyard was like a suckering machine, constantly producing new shoots for the grapes.
meanings.sent5: The daisy plant was suckering vigorously, showing signs of healthy growth.

meanings.sent1: The con artist was suckering unsuspecting victims with promises of easy money.
meanings.sent2: She realized too late that the online seller had suckered her into buying a fake product.
meanings.sent3: The tricky magician was suckering the audience with his sleight of hand tricks.
meanings.sent4: The scammer was like a master at suckering people into giving away their personal information.
meanings.sent5: The smooth talker was suckering everyone with his charming lies.

meanings.sent1: The cheap knockoff product was suckering customers who didn't know the difference.
meanings.sent2: The faulty appliance was suckering buyers into thinking it was a good deal.
meanings.sent3: The fake designer bag was suckering fashion enthusiasts who wanted a bargain.
meanings.sent4: The subpar service was suckering clients into believing they were getting a good deal.
meanings.sent5: The low-quality material was suckering customers into purchasing overpriced items.
